block.p: For some executives, a yearly compensation package that includes a cash bonus must seem positively quaint. These days, most chief executives are asking for and receiving stock options as the predominant form of long-term incentives, according to Howard B. Goldsmith, vice president at the Segal Company, a human relations consulting concern in Manhattan. In its annual executive compensation report on companies with up to $200 million in revenue, Segal found that the stock-option warriors -- those whose compensation came primarily from stock options -- were in the high-technology area.
As a group, chief executives of these companies were paid 3,156 percent of their salary in stock options last year, Segal reported.

For some executives, a yearly compensation package that includes a cash bonus must seem positively quaint. These days, most chief executives are asking for and receiving stock options as the predominant form of long-term incentives, according to Howard B. Goldsmith, vice president at the Segal Company, a human relations consulting concern in Manhattan. In its annual executive compensation report on companies with up to $200 million in revenue, Segal found that the stock-option warriors -- those whose compensation came primarily from stock options -- were in the high-technology area.
As a group, chief executives of these companies were paid 3,156 percent of their salary in stock options last year, Segal reported.

To be sure, stock options are well represented in all eight industry areas tracked by Segal. On the low end, leaders of companies in the fabricated metal/ wood area had to settle for options that amounted to just 37 percent of salary. Even so, those chief executives earned $288,000, on average, in 1999, in salaries and cash bonuses; that is $8,000 more than their high-tech counterparts. ''Upside potential and risk,'' Mr. Goldsmith said, ''that's what stock options are all about.''
